edu.udel.cis.vsl.sarl.preuniverse.common

Class ExpressionSubstituter

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.udel.cis.vsl.sarl.preuniverse.common.ExpressionSubstituter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Transform<SymbolicExpression,SymbolicExpression>, UnaryOperator<SymbolicExpression>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BoundCleaner, CanonicalRenamer, MapSubstituter, NameSubstituter, SimpleSubstituter

    public abstract class ExpressionSubstituter
extends java.lang.Object
implements UnaryOperator<SymbolicExpression>

    A generic, abstract class for performing substitutions on symbolic expressions. Concrete classes must implement the interface ExpressionSubstituter.SubstituterState, which is used store anything about the state of the search through the expression. They must also implement the method newState() to produce the initial ExpressionSubstituter.SubstituterState. They should also override any or all of the protected methods here.

    Idea: instead of recursion: try using stacks. workStack and resultStack. In the following, the LEFT side is the top of each stack. That is where elements are pushed and popped. Procedure: loop until work stack is empty. Take object off the top of the work stack. If the object is an operator, perform that operation on the result stack. If the object is a symbolic object: If you can simplify it in one step (by cache or because it is primitive), push the simplified result onto the result stack. Otherwise push onto the work stack: the operator followed by the arguments. Question: how do you know where a collection begins and ends? Might have to include "size" as part of collection argument. 

     work:  (X*Y)+Z
 result:
 
 work:  (X*Y) Z +
 result:
 
 work: X Y * Z +
 result:
 
 work: Y * Z +
 result: X1
 
 work: * Z +
 result: X2 X1
 
 work: Z +
 result: X1*X2
 
 work: +
 result: X3 X1*X2
 
 work:
 result: (X1*X2)+X3

    • Method Detail

      • apply

        public SymbolicExpression apply(SymbolicExpression expression)
        Performs substitution on the given symbolic expression. First looks in cache to see if substitution was already applied and returns old result if so. Otherwise, applies the substitution algorithm to the expression, caches, and returns the result.
        Specified by:
        apply in interface Transform<SymbolicExpression,SymbolicExpression>
        Parameters:
        expression - a non-null symbolic expression
        Returns:
        the result of performing substitution on expression
